prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for buying pregnant wife yoga pass for her birthday
My wife is 16 weeks pregnant.  She has a something called hypermesis which is "morning sickness" all the time, even waking up in the middle of the night to vomit.   I told her to ask her doctor for a medical leave so she is currently on temporary disability.  She stays in bed most of the day and only leaves the house to go to the hospital where she gets IV fluids for dehydration/vitamin deficiency.     
I know I always feel better when I exercise and it helps with depression.  I think she is getting depressed because she misses her job.  I think she should leave the house and get some fresh air and stretch, so I got her a yoga pass for her birthday.   I researched local studios and found one that had prenatal yoga.   When she got the email gift certificate while I was at work, she didn't call to say thank you.  When I got home, I asked her if she got the email and she just gave me a look.  I could tell she didn't like my present.  She says she is too sick to do yoga.   Ok, maybe.   She thinks it is a rude present and that I am "tone deaf."  I can get her another present...don't know what.   I don't think my present makes me a bad person, though.   She might feel better soon and want to take yoga classes.  She told her friends about it and they agreed with her that I am being an asshole.  I think it is rude to be so critical of my present.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that he bought his pregnant wife a prenatal yoga pass for her birthday, but she didn't like it. She has hypermesis, which is severe morning sickness, and she's on temporary disability. He thought exercise might help with her depression from missing work, but she's too sick to do yoga and thinks the gift was tone-deaf.

First, I need to consider the author's intentions. He wanted to help her by encouraging her to get out and exercise, which he knows helps with depression. He researched prenatal yoga, so he tried to find something appropriate. But she's extremely sick, staying in bed, and the yoga pass might not be feasible for her current condition. 

On the other hand, he didn't consult her before buying the gift. Maybe she felt that he didn't consider her actual situation. Even though he had good intentions, she might feel that he's not respecting her current limitations. The friends agreed with her that he was an asshole, which suggests that maybe there's a cultural or social norm where this gesture isn't appropriate when someone is that unwell.

He didn't ask her what she needed, and she's in a state where she's not able to engage in such activities. Even if he thought it would help, forcing or assuming that she wants to do something when she's so ill might not be the right approach. The key might be whether he overstepped by not considering her feelings and current health status, despite his good intentions. So maybe he's in the wrong for not asking her preferences and not recognizing that she might not be up for it. But then again, he's trying to help. It's a bit of a gray area. However, the fact that she felt it was rude and her friends agreed might mean that he was wrong.
